Description: Rim and neck sherd of Attic black-figured pottery neck-amphora; interior glazed black; exterior: black rim with added red bands top and bottom; below, black-figure decoration consisting of three male figures: of the central figure, a boxer, bearded head, right arm, part of torso and buttock remain; added red on hair and beard; only the forehead of his opponent is preserved; to right a trainer, holding a stick, stands facing left. The top of the rim is recessed for the fitting of a lid.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 126, pl. XXXVIII, no. 352.4)
CVA Boston I / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum, USA Fasc. 14, Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, Fasc. 1 (p. 43, pl. 58, no. 184)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 232, no. 184)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0854)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4798 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
